<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 324, 293]]<|/det|>
## FURTHER MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9231/33  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 298, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Further Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 30 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 392, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 280, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 358, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 868, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 485, 574]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 605]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 856, 636]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 636, 777, 652]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m} \text{s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 681, 220, 696]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 697, 730, 728]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50. The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(m\) is attached to one end of a light inextensible string of length \(a\). The other end of the string is attached to a fixed point \(O\) on a smooth horizontal plane. The particle \(P\) moves in horizontal circles about \(O\). The tension in the string is \(4mg\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 744, 152]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(a\) and \(g\), the time that \(P\) takes to make one complete revolution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 583, 136, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 583, 922, 617]]<|/det|>
A particle \(Q\) of mass \(m \mathrm{kg}\) falls from rest under gravity. The motion of \(Q\) is resisted by a force of magnitude \(m kv \mathrm{N}\), where \(v \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) is the speed of \(Q\) at time \(t\) s and \(k\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 628, 479, 647]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(v\) in terms of \(g, k\) and \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 628, 920, 647]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
A particle \(Q\) of mass \(m\) is attached to a fixed point \(O\) by a light inextensible string of length \(a\). The particle moves in complete vertical circles about \(O\). The points \(A\) and \(B\) are on the path of \(Q\) with \(AB\) a diameter of the circle. \(OA\) makes an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) with the downward vertical through \(O\) and \(OB\) makes an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) with the upward vertical through \(O\). The speed of \(Q\) when it is at \(A\) is \(2\sqrt{ag}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 148, 860, 170]]<|/det|>
Given that \(T_{A}\) and \(T_{B}\) are the tensions in the string at \(A\) and \(B\) respectively, find the ratio \(T_{A}\colon T_{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 149, 917, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 79, 757, 276]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 293, 920, 358]]<|/det|>
Two uniform smooth spheres \(A\) and \(B\) of equal radii each have mass \(m\). The two spheres are each moving with speed \(u\) on a horizontal surface when they collide. Immediately before the collision \(A\)'s direction of motion makes an angle of \(\alpha^{\circ}\) with the line of centres, and \(B\)'s direction of motion is perpendicular to that of \(A\) (see diagram). The coefficient of restitution between the spheres is \(e\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 370, 826, 390]]<|/det|>
Immediately after the collision, \(B\) moves in a direction at right angles to the line of centres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 401, 143, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 396, 353, 420]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\tan \alpha = \frac{1 + e}{1 - e}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 401, 920, 420]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 621, 89]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\tan \alpha = 2\), find the speed of \(A\) after the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 89]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is projected with speed \(u\) at an angle \(\theta\) above the horizontal from a point \(O\) on a horizontal plane and moves freely under gravity. The direction of motion of \(P\) makes an angle \(\alpha\) above the horizontal when \(P\) first reaches three-quarters of its greatest height.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 144, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 359, 153]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\tan \alpha = \frac{1}{2} \tan \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 134, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\tan \theta = \frac{4}{3}\), find the horizontal distance travelled by \(P\) when it first reaches three-quarters of its greatest height. Give your answer in terms of \(u\) and \(g\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 69, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 87, 744, 173]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 190, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
One end of a light spring of natural length \(a\) and modulus of elasticity \(4mg\) is attached to a fixed point \(O\). The other end of the spring is attached to a particle \(A\) of mass \(km\), where \(k\) is a constant. Initially the spring lies at rest on a smooth horizontal surface and has length \(a\). A second particle \(B\), of mass \(m\), is moving towards \(A\) with speed \(\sqrt{\frac{4}{3} ga}\) along the line of the spring from the opposite direction to \(O\) (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 286, 920, 322]]<|/det|>
The particles \(A\) and \(B\) collide and coalesce. At a point \(C\) in the subsequent motion, the length of the spring is \(\frac{3}{4} a\) and the speed of the combined particle is half of its initial speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 333, 146, 351]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 333, 311, 351]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 333, 920, 351]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
At the point \(C\) the horizontal surface becomes rough, with coefficient of friction \(\mu\) between the combined particle and the surface. The deceleration of the combined particle at \(C\) is \(\frac{9}{20} g\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 137]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 120, 313, 137]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 137]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 72, 567, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
